S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Comparison of the logistic regression model, augmented-variable model, and power-likelihood model. In all models, i=1,…,N𝑖1…𝑁i=1,\ldots,N denotes the observation index. In the logistic regression model, k=1,…,p𝑘1…𝑝k=1,\ldots,p denotes the covariate index. In the auxiliary-variable and power-likelihood models, j=1,…,J𝑗1…𝐽j=1,\ldots,J denotes the client index, k=1,…,pj𝑘1…subscript𝑝𝑗k=1,\ldots,p_{j} denotes the covariate index for client j𝑗j, and m≠j𝑚𝑗m\neq j denotes the index for clients other than j𝑗j. The auxiliary-variable zi​jsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗z_{ij} is introduced for each observation i𝑖i and client j𝑗j in both the auxiliary-variable and power-likelihood models.
references: Here, we fit a logistic regression model and the corresponding augmented-variable and power-likelihood model to a synthetic data set. The descriptions for all three model variations are defined in Table 1.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2: The eight combinations of model and inference algorithms we run. The columns denote the three models: the true model (i.e. the true data-generating model), the augmented-variable model, and the power-likelihood model. The rows denote three inference algorithms: MCMC (specifically the No-U-Turn sampler) and two “federated” variants, represented as two differing variational approximations, namely mean-field VI
S5.T2.table:
True model Augmented-variable Power-likelihood
MCMC ✓ ✓ ✓
Mean-field VI ✓ ✓ ✓
Amortized VI ✗ ✓ ✓
references:
We generate the synthetic data from the underlying logistic regression model, with random standard Gaussian noise added to the linear predictor for each observation. The number of observations is n=500𝑛500n=500, and the number of covariates is
p=20𝑝20p=20. We generate all elements of the data matrix 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} from the standard Gaussian distribution. In this example, we compare the performance of the three models, fit using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), in particular with the No-U-Turn sampler (NUTS) fit in NumPyro [28], and two different variational approximations, a mean-field approximation and the amortized approximation. Note that the posterior approximation for the parameters 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta} and b𝑏b are the same throughout the two approximations, and the only difference comes in the variational approximation for the parameters 𝒛𝒛\bm{z}. Table 2 shows the combination of models and algorithms that we consider fitting in this example.

references: Table 3 presents the test predictive accuracy and average test log-likelihood for the split NN and the hierarchical Bayes split NN with different values of the hyperparameter ρ𝜌\rho (ρ=1,5,10𝜌1510\rho={1,5,10}). The results demonstrate that all variants of the hierarchical Bayes split NN outperform the standard split NN, with better performance observed for smaller values of ρ𝜌\rho, which is expected, because using higher values of ρ𝜌\rho is analogous to reducing the amount of signal that the set of auxiliary variables contains regarding the mean, which is the value of interest. Notably, higher variance is observed for larger values of ρ𝜌\rho, which is intuitive as it introduces additional variance to the model.
